Born on August 13, 1954, in London, England, Laurie displayed a penchant for performing from a young age. His career took off in the late '70s as he became a prominent actor and musician, earning recognition both on stage and in the classroom.

As a teenager, Laurie attended Eton College, where he continued to develop his acting skills, winning numerous accolades, including the prestigious Eton Drama Prize. His talent was not confined to the stage; Laurie was also a gifted pianist, which led him to become the frontman for the progressive rock band, Pornography. The band, however, disbanded in 1982.

Laurie's first major success came in 1983 when he landed the role of Dr. Gregory House in the British medical drama "House." This marked the beginning of his enduring connection to the series, which aired in the UK for four seasons. His portrayal of the brilliant but eccentric, misanthropic doctor earned him worldwide recognition.

In 2004, "House" made the leap to American television, catapulting Laurie into the international spotlight. For ten seasons, audiences across the globe tuned in to watch the compelling chemistry between Laurie and his character and co-stars. He reprised his role for the series' final season in 2013, receiving critical acclaim for his ability to evolve the character's complexity and vulnerability.

On the stage, he has earned accolades for his performances in works like "Hamlet," "The Merry Wives of Windsor," and "Closer."
